item.title: Tic Tac Tie
item.description:
Tic Tac Tie was an accidental pun made while discussing the program’s computer logic it used against the player. It was suppose to be simple and aim to always create a draw. Hence the ‘tie’.

Unfortunately I did find one win condition it can’t seem to beat.

Which is okay as it was my first ‘AI’ I’ve made to play against someone.

I didn’t do much design on this one. I may revist it. Main goal was to see how quickly I could go from concept in my head to fully functional. I had to get up early take a long car ride downtown. I felt I had all the kinks and issues worked out in my head. How i’d style it, the html layout and the javascript.

So it felt great to write HUGE chunks of it with little testing before finishing. Still a lot of micro tweaks, but overall it works great.

Tic Tac Tie, as usual you can find the code on my github.

item.title: Pomodoro Technique
item.description:
I recently did a project that required you to create a Pomodoro timer, a productivity tool. I am a big fan of their technique. Following it, even loosely, has greatly improved my ability to focus, study and in general knock out projects.

Check out their website to get an idea what it’s about.

Pomodoro Technique Website

I am really proud of this, I think its not only the best looking app I’ve but the most functional too. Here is the link currently to my timer Promodoro Timer

I used the Jquery UI A LOT less this time. I used it for some warning boxes on inputs and the slide out settings, but the rest of the animation is just custom CSS animation. Great practice learning that as I feel vastly more comfortable rolling my own animation.

Comment below and let me know what you think. Hopefully you find it as useful as I do.

item.title: Twitch Watcher
item.description:
Fairly straight forward app. Handling JSON from a get request but a lot more information coming in and not consistent. So that helped learn some new obstacles and how to hurdle them.

I am liking the idea of going clean and simple. The list is rather simple to update, so creating one designed for someone else favorite streamers would be trivial.

Twitch Watcher

One thing that was exciting this project was saving results in a remote area like a ‘temp’ database. Found a website

Browsers rant

Latest frustration has been Firefox, it seems like Opera, Safari Chrome and even Edge all have similar features and the way they deal with them. Firefox on the other hand is the edge case browser now. It seems it mostly due to being very strict in following the specifications, so I guess they can’t be faulted.

item.title: Local Weather Project
item.description:
Project was creating a weather app that gets your current location via browser. I used the recommend weather app API OpenWeatherMap. Relatively straight forward project. Few days ago I did the project with the random quote API, so that was very helpful here. Parsing the JSON took a short learning curve but otherwise not very troublesome.

Really starting to get a very comfortable feel with CSS. CSS was probably the more intimidating of the HTML frontend stuff. It always seems like a fight to get something the way you want it. Lately that doesn’t seem to be the case.

Well here it is and my code will always be available on my github : Live Local Weather App

CSS Frustrations /rant-warning

Things like clearfix on everything, negative margins and in simple things like fighting a solution to center stuff.

Just seemed like everything was a ‘hacky’ solution. Things are getting a lot more clear for me and I am sure that in part to be able to exclusively use CSS3 and ditch a lot of the old hacky stuff due to browser compatibility but also getting a better understanding of the basics have been great.

Next few projects will have more focus on making things look much cleaner and more attractive.

item.title: Jekyll and Blogging
item.description:
Got Jekyll up and running for the start of my blog. Gonna use this to motivate myself to spend some time reflecting on the projects I’ve been doing. Trying to learn a lot in the timeframe I have has definitely crammed more than I can reflect.

With these next more freeform projects coming up I should be able to test myself in how far I have come and give myself opportunities to put myself outside my comfort zone.

Jekyll was a fun process. This theme is very nice, a few tweaks here and there to change out some images, color theme and social icons.

Setting up

Some reason Github wouldn’t build my pages even though locally I wasn’t getting any errors. So instead I’ve set it up locally to build the site and then push it to my git page via a batch file.

This also required having a separate dev config too, which was interesting. On my side everything build flawlessly and pushing it seems to have no issues as it no longer requiring Github to builds the pages. This also means I can use whatever plug-in I desire.
